job_description: The Housing, Economic and Infrastructure Planning (HEIP) Division advises the Chair and City Planning Commission on housing, economic and infrastructure policy issues and conducts housing, economic and infrastructure planning studies for the agency.  As part of the Departmentâ€™s recovery activities following Hurricane Sandy, and funded through federal Hazard Mitigation Plan Grant (HMPG) funding, the Department is launching a study to improve the resiliency of the cityâ€™s industrial areas, with a focus on flood resiliency. The study will provide recommendations to reduce hazards and challenges related to severe weather events for businesses and residents in the Cityâ€™s flood zones; identify appropriate emergency preparedness guidelines for industrial businesses in the flood zone; promote cost-effective physical or operational changes for businesses to reduce flood risk; and identify strategies to address challenges with financing and insurance for industrial businesses located within the flood zone. The Department is seeking a City Planner to manage this study.  Under direct supervision from the Director of Industry Studies, and with latitude for independent initiative and judgment, the City Planner will perform basic research, analysis and planning activities in the field of city planning. The planner will be part of an interdisciplinary team, managed by the Waterfront and Strategic Planning divisions, focused on resiliency within the agency, and will be providing expertise on industrial resiliency to the rest of this team. The temporary position is funded for 15 months.   RESPONSIBILITIES:  â€¢ Manage the collection, storage, maintenance and dissemination of data relevant to hazard mitigation for industrial sites in flood-prone areas; perform preliminary analyses. â€¢ Assemble and presents statistical and narrative materials relating to existing, proposed zoning or land use conditions within industrial areas. â€¢ Compile and abstract materials and prepare factual reports on population characteristics, land use, zoning, retail activity and economic development and other neighborhood characteristics.  â€¢ Map survey and administrative data related to risk mitigation in flood-prone industrial areas to illustrate spatial relationships.  â€¢ Manage the collection of data by survey, investigation or research on special planning problems; may prepare reports, diagrams, drawings and graphics relating to strategies to mitigate hazards and reduce damage to property for businesses and residents in the Cityâ€™s flood zones; assists in elementary planning of land use.  â€¢ Compile all information into clear, well-written report or presentations. â€¢ Interview members of the community and representatives of public and private agencies to obtain their assessment of local problems, needs opportunities, preferences, policies and programs. â€¢ Interview owners of businesses, property owners, industrial real estate brokers and developers, and providers of insurance and financing to identify obstacles to risk mitigation for development in the flood-prone industrial areas.  â€¢ Represent the department at meetings of civic, business and community groups, community boards, and public agencies. â€¢ Create and organize graphic and written materials for presentation to the City Planning Commission, other governmental agencies, and the public. â€¢ Manage administration of grant materials, including preparation of quarterly reporting documents required by city, state and federal agencies.

job_description: The Tenant Interim Lease (TIL) program in the Office of Asset and Property Management, assists tenant associations in City-owned buildings to become tenant-owned cooperatives.  Under the general direction of the Assistant Commissioner of the Division of Property Management and Client Services and with latitude for independent judgment and decision-making, HPD seeks a Director for the TIL program.  The Director of TIL oversees the day to day operations of the TIL program consisting of 159 TIL buildings and 140 Tenant Associations (TA).  General responsbilities include the  1) management, monitoring, and implementation of program policies and protocols, including by-laws and net leases, to ensure compliance amongst TAs and accountability amongst program staff and contracted training providers; 2) ensuring property and timely building maintenance practices throughout the portfolio; 3) ensuring training opportunities are well coordinated and relevant; 4) contract administration and management; 5) management of repair budgets and repair needs; 6) supervision of a field team of 22 staff, and 7) other duties as assigned by the Assistant Commissioner.  The Director will manage the implementation of updated program policies, including the training of TAs and staff.  The Director will identify operational gaps and design more strategic workflows. The Director will represent HPD in external meetings with other city agencies and stakeholders.  This position requires fieldwork and evening hours and weekend hours to meet with TAs.   This position will be on-call evenings, weekends, and holidays to handle emergency situations in TIL buildings.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A four-year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and six years of satisfactory, full-time, progressively responsible experience in real property management, at least 18 months of which must have been in a managerial capacity involving the supervision of a large staff of property management agents and/or housing development specialists and requiring independent decision-making concerning program management or planning, allocation of resources and the scheduling and assignment of work. ''Progressively responsible experience'' must  be demonstrated by a work history of promotions and/or assumption of increasingly responsible duties and assignments. Experience in building construction or renovation; management of residential, commercial, industrial, or waterfront properties, including both renting and operating; or site management in connection with housing or with reconstruction/rehabilitation projects; supervision of receivership, tenant relocation and anti-abandonment work in housing and other properties, and buildings owned, managed, to be acquired by the City, or at risk of being abandoned; or building maintenance will be accepted up to a maximum of three years toward meeting the general requirements; or    2. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college and four years of experience described in ''1'' above, including eighteen months of experience in managerial capacity; or    3. A satisfactory combination of education and/or experience equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. However, all candidates must have eighteen months of managerial experience. Education at an accredited college or university may be substituted for general work experience (but not for the 18 months of managerial experience described above) at the rate of 60 college semester credits for one year of acceptable experience up to a maximum of 4 years of college for 2 years of experience.    To be acceptable, experience in property management must have included both renting and operating the managed properties. Experience in renting must have included interviewing prospective tenants, qualifying tenants' income and background, and/or assuring that vacancies are ready for occupancy. Experience in operating must have included overseeing maintenance and repair of building operating systems, and overseeing staff to assure that necessary work is properly completed.    To be acceptable, experience in site management must have included on-site rental and maintenance of buildings.    To be acceptable, experience in relocation must have included negotiation with tenants to surrender leases for cash consideration or for an alternative site, and determining tenant eligibility for benefits.

job_description: The Office of Chief Medical Examiner investigates cases of persons who die within New York City from criminal violence, by accident, by suicide, suddenly when in apparent health, when unattended by a physician, in a correctional facility or in any suspicious or unusual manner or where an application is made pursuant to law for a permit to cremate a body of a person.    We exist to provide answers in support of families, victims and community during times of profound need.	  The core values of the OCME are to put the mission of the agency first, to be truly dedicated and to have integrity in every aspect of our professional life.   JOB DESCRIPTION  Under the direction of the Executive Agency Attorney, with latitude for independent judgment and unreviewed action and decision, the selected candidate will have duties which include but are not limited to:  Assist Agency personnel with legal aspects of areas of responsibility and resolve day-to-day Agency issues.  Advise the Chief of Laboratories, the General Counsel, and other Executive Staff regarding legal issues concerning the OCME laboratories.  Supervise highly technical litigation discovery responses for OCME Laboratories.    Assist in compliance with subpoenas and court orders served upon the Agency.	  Resolve legal issues involving forensic analysis in OCME laboratories, quality assurance, laboratory protocols, and the retention of forensic samples.  Coordinate Agency response regarding legal compliance of CODIS and LDIS DNA Databases.  Draft contracts pertaining to outside jurisdiction requests for forensic testing.  Draft, review and edit Non Disclosure Agreements, Data Sharing Agreements, and Beta Testing Agreements pertaining to OCME laboratories, as well as contract specifications for specialized laboratory services.  Prepare and/or supervise all Agency responses to Freedom of Information Law requests.    Review all research projects, surveillance studies and human subjects research submissions involving the Agency.  Coordinate as needed with DOHMH Institutional Review Board.  Review and analyze local, state and federal legislative recommendations and proposals related to forensic science and subject matters which may impact the Agency.   Assist with resolution of Dispute cases where intervention by the Legal Department is necessary.  Communicate with next of kin, otherwise authorized persons, attorneys, and/or estate administrators, as necessary, in communicating Agency requirements in resolving dispute cases.    Assist with coordinating Agency actions related to paternity requests, tissue specimen hold requests, and release of tissue specimens.  As needed, coordinate Agency outreach to the Cityâ€™s Conflicts of Interest Board.  Assist with Agency actions regarding regulation and management of DNA sample collection consent forms for OCME and non-OCME personnel.  Perform other duties as assigned.  SPECIAL NOTE  1. Selected candidates will be required to provide a DNA sample by swabbing.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. Admission to the New York State Bar; and either ''2'' or ''3'' below.  2. One year of satisfactory United States legal experience subsequent to admission to any state bar; or   3. Six months of satisfactory service as an Agency Attorney Interne (30086).    Incumbents must remain Members of the New York State Bar in good standing for the duration of this employment.  In addition to meeting the minimum Qualification Requirements:  To be assigned to Assignment Level (AL) II, candidates must have one year of experience at Assignment Level I or two years of comparable legal experience subsequent to admission to the bar, in the areas of law related to the assignment. To be assigned to AL III candidates must have two years of experience in Assignment Levels I and/or II or three years of comparable legal experience subsequent to admission to the bar, in the areas of law related to the assignment.
preferred_skills: Experience with DNA analysis, scientific laboratory procedures, confidentiality of DNA profiles and information, and criminal prosecution/defense

job_description: The New York City Law Department is seeking a Litigation Support Director in the Litigation Support Division. The Department is one of the largest law offices in New York City and one of the largest public law offices in the country. The Department's 650 lawyers handle more than 90,000 cases and transactions each year. The Department's attorneys represent the City on a vast array of civil litigation and in the criminal prosecution of juveniles. The Department also counsels the Mayor, elected officials, the City and all its agencies.  The Litigation Support Director will manage and supervise attorney, paralegal and client agency staff.  Deploy and allocate resources effectively across multiple Agency locations.  Analyze staffing needs, create budgets and secure resources as necessary. Manage and supervise processes to ensure proper tracking, handling and processing of collected data.  Determine legal strategy based upon evaluation of evidence collected; including determinations regarding relevance and materiality of evidence.  Collaborate directly with Agency General Counsel and staff to resolve discovery issues. Become familiar with City agenciesâ€™ IT systems and management, in order to assist with the collection and cataloguing of electronic and paper evidence.  Keep abreast of new developments in municipal liability, e-discovery law and legal technology. Provide general advice and counsel on best practices and matters concerning organizational oversight and use of IT systems involved in litigation.
minimum_qual_requirements: J.D. from an accredited law school and admitted to practice in New York State.  At least two years of supervisory experience, with experience supervising off-site staff preferred.  At least four years of litigation and discovery experience, including substantial experience in municipal tort law. Demonstrated exceptional organizational and analytical abilities; strong oral and written communication skills, including the ability to interact with and develop collaborative relationships with both Law Department and Agency personnel.  Ability to work both independently and as part of a team. Understanding of and exposure to litigation involving the exchange of documentary and electronic discovery.

job_description: As part of the Mayorâ€™s Office of Operations, HHS Accelerator and Connect are the Cityâ€™s go-to resource for harnessing digital tools and capabilities to improve the lives of low-income and vulnerable New Yorkers, with the policy, management and technical expertise to help produce better outcomes for residents.  The unit currently operates HHS Accelerator, Worker Connect, and ACCESS NYC.   â€¢   HHS Accelerator is a transformational initiative to reengineer, simplify and speed the      procurement process for City agencies and client and community based service      organizations by implementing a series of policy reforms, restructuring of rules and      regulations, centralizing portions of procurement oversights and building a web-based      system to support these reforms to dramatically shift the Cityâ€™s procurement of health and      human services.   â€¢  Worker Connect, a data sharing technology that allows case workers to see real-time     information about clients drawn from multiple City sources. Users only access information     that they have been authorized to view based on their role and all applicable laws and     regulations.  â€¢   ACCESS NYC, a website that allows New Yorkers to screen for eligibility for over 30 City,      State, and Federal benefit programs. Depending on the benefit, residents can apply online,      print out pre-populated application forms, and determine agency locations where they can      go to directly apply for services.   Together, these initiatives break information silos through the use of modernized technology and coordinated agency practices to more efficiently and effectively provide health and human services to New Yorkers. Our dedicated team is growing through adding new skillsets to enhance and expand the current products and create new digital services. Joining this team is an opportunity to use your expertise in digital services to create meaningful impact and help improve the lives of millions of New Yorkers.   As part of this unit, the External Affairs and Client Experience Team develops and implements communication, learning, and partner engagement strategies to promote quality experiences for users of information technology systems managed or supported by the office.  In addition, the team collaborates across the organization to ensure high levels of public visibility, alignment of messaging, responsiveness to emerging policy or business issues affecting NYCâ€™s service capacity, and advancement of new enterprise priorities.  Reporting directly to the Associate Director, Learning Management, the Management Advisor will be critical to initiative implementation. The Management Advisor will partner with team leaders to develop and implement communication, learning, and engagement strategies which result in a high quality experience when utilizing any information technology systems or projects directly managed by the office. job_description: Under the direction of the Assistant Commissioner for Planning, the Director of Manhattan Planning develops, implements, and manages all planning activities for the borough of Manhattan.  The Director is responsible for building and managing a team of energetic, thoughtful, and engaged planners that work together to manage the project entitlement process and environmental reviews; and, ensure that development, design, and planning proposals meet HPD and other city policy objectives.  The goal of the Planning Division is to ensure that HPD investments are leveraging and incentivizing other public and private investments to achieve broader community objectives that strengthen the social, economic, and physical health of neighborhoods.  The Borough Planning units consist of teams of planners responsible for managing the entitlement and development approval process for the development of city-owned parcels and/or projects financed or sponsored by HPD for the development of affordable housing.  All planners in the Planning Division are expected to perform similar duties and responsibilities to ensure a flexible and multi-disciplined team.  Selected duties for the Borough Planning team include analyzing development trends, and neighborhood and market dynamics; land use and zoning analysis; coordinating with Predevelopment Planners in the requests for proposals review and selection process; and, managing the critical path toward project entitlement and development financial closing.  The Borough Planning team works collaboratively with other units of the Division of Planning and participates in neighborhood planning efforts.  The Borough Planning team works with other New York City agencies, such as the Economic Development Corporation and the Department of City Planning,  as well as for- and non- profit housing and community developers, Community Boards and local organizations, public officials, and neighborhood residents through the predevelopment process.  The Director of Manhattan Planning, and all planners within the Division of Planning, is expected to participate and assist in neighborhood workshops as necessary.

Graduation from an accredited United States Law School may be substituted for two (2) years of non-managerial  experience.

job_description: Headed by the agencyâ€™s General Counsel/Deputy Commissioner for Legal Affairs, the Legal Affairs Division serves as the in-house legal department for the New York City Department of Finance. The Division provides professional and comprehensive legal advice and services in support of a full range of City tax and other revenue-related matters handled by the Department of Financeâ€™s operating divisions. Legal Affairs attorneys handle diverse legal areas including New York City real property taxes and exemptions; City business income and excise taxes; collections; parking violations; treasury; land registry; FOIL; employment law; among other things.   Reporting to the Director, the Parking Division focuses on parking-related matters including drafting fraud petitions and bringing cases to reinstatement hearings, drafting parking related legislation and rules, advising operating divisions, preparing cases for administrative review, working with the Cityâ€™s Law Department on parking related litigation matters, communicating with the general public and resolving complex issues arising from the boot/tow of their vehicle(s), and preparing and signing collection and/or enforcement legal documents. The selected attorney will handle a range of parking and parking enforcement related legal matters.  The attorney will also be responsible for working with the Director and other staff to develop and prepare documents for fraud reinstatement hearings and represent the agency at the hearings.   Under direction, with wide latitude for independent judgment and unreviewed action and decision, the selected candidate may handle the following complex related matters:   â€¢  Perform legal work involving issues of fact and questions of law, including parking law,     CPLR, Vehicle and Traffic Law. â€¢  Perform legal research and draft memorandum, legal responses and other documents as     needed.  Prepare, review and/or sign legal collection and enforcement documents as needed. â€¢  Research and draft parking related agency rules, regulations and guidance.  â€¢  Serve as liaison with the Law Department on agency related litigation. Work with managers     and staff in the operating divisions to be able to provide necessary information and     responses to review and defend any claims or actions filed against the agency. â€¢  As needed, prepare petitions for administrative hearings including parking fraud     reinstatement hearings and to assist the public directly with complex legal problems resulting from the Sheriff Boot Program. â€¢  Represent the agency at administrative hearings and in other forums such as small claims     court, and parking fraud reinstatement hearings as may be needed. The attorney will be     required to travel to all boroughs for hearings as needed.  â€¢  Handle general legal matters and special assignments and serve as â€œof counselâ€ to the     Special Assistant Corporation Counsel. â€¢  Research and draft legal responses to claims or actions filed against the agency as needed. â€¢  Assist in providing legal counsel to the agencyâ€™s operational staff on other areas as assigned by Division managers and/or the General Counsel.  â€¢  Participate on division and agency projects.

job_description: The candidate will be responsible for the management, programing and implementation of a number of Street Improvement Projects (SIP).  The candidate will be accountable for all software programing, modeling and management for these projects.  Must be fluent in Synchro, Highway Capacity Software (HCS), VISSIM and Aimsun programs.  All input, analysis and calibration of the results delivered from the models will be the candidateâ€™s responsibility.  The candidate will be responsible to manage all traffic signals that will be redesigned, retimed and/or reconstructed based on the scope of each SIP.  Managing the SIP will include the reconstruction of over 200 intersections, installation of new signals at 30 intersections, modify 180 additional signals and retime 560 signals.  The candidate will be reporting to the Chief of Signals and ITS Engineering and providing assistance related to the SIP projects, traffic signal approvals, traffic signal design and installation.  The candidate will also be assisting in a number of Vision Zero initiatives.  Synchro and Aimsun model runs will be conducted simulating the proposed recommendations and evaluating the various signal coordination and progression sequences along the studied corridors.  Performs and reviews Signal Warrant, Highway Capacity Analysis, and Traffic Impact Studies.  The candidate may need to resolve problems with a number of Project Managers from other Divisions/Units that arise in meeting schedules and costs.  The candidate will also be working with the University Transportation Research Center (UTRC) on Vision Zero initiatives, such as projects related to Pedestrian and Cyclists Safety by using ITS Technology in NYC.  Will perform simulation runs on ITS-based countermeasures for reducing pedestrian injuries, conflicts and fatalities.  Maintains a management information system to provide data for the planning and control for project development.  Oversees the consultant selection and contracting process, and manages these contracts.  May incidentally perform duties of subordinates.  Corresponds with the Consultants and other Agencies.

job_description: The NYC Vaccines for Children (VFC) Program distributes federally funded vaccines to private practices, hospitals and clinics to immunize children age 0 through 18 years who are covered by Medicaid, are uninsured, native American/Alaskan Eskimo, or whose insurance does not cover the cost of a vaccine.   In New York City (NYC), 72% of children receive vaccines distributed through the VFC program.   During Fiscal Year 2014, around 3.0 million vaccine doses, valued at approximately 130 million dollars, were distributed through the NYC VFC program to over 1,400 VFC-enrolled providers.       DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:   --Oversee all PQA field activities to ensure compliance with all VFC requirements.  -- Supervise 1 Public Health Advisor and 2 Public Health Epidemiologists Level-II , the latter of whom are each responsible for supervising 4 or 5 PHE Level I or Supervising PHA field staff.  -- Conduct quality assurance activities to ensure accuracy of data entered by field staff.  -- Review and analyze field staff work progress and provide feedback regularly.  -- Review and analyze data from multiple systems and data sources to ensure that the unit is meeting field visit goals and objectives.  --Serve as the liaison for evaluation and follow-up of possible cases of fraud and abuse cases identified by field staff.  --Ensure that all provider referrals are assigned, tracked, and resolved in a timely manner by field staff.  -- Analyze data and develop strategies and reports to ensure that follow-up requirements are met.  --Prepare and present narrative, statistical and administrative reports as necessary.  --Assist with special projects and unit priorities; assist in preparing and conducting periodic trainings for field staff.  --Coordinate actions with other Bureau units, including the Citywide Immunization Registry (CIR) and Vaccine Management Unit (VMU) to improve Immunization practices among providers.

job_description: The New York City Department of Correction has a career opportunity for an experienced professional to serve as the Director of Strategic Partnerships & Community Engagement. This position is a vital role in advancing the mission and reform agenda of the DOC by strengthening business and community partnerships, and increasing visibility through community engagement and outreach. Under general supervision and with latitude to exercise independent judgement and decision making, the successful candidate will support and promote the DOC brand to external and internal partners. The incumbent will also serve as liaison to the DOC, business and community organizations; identify and develop opportunities to collaborate with other organizations on community engagement activities; foster collaborative efforts with internal and external stakeholders, community and business partners; develop and maintain positive working relationships with community leaders and community organizations for the purpose of building partnerships and expanding human capital initiatives; establish and maintain partnerships with community organizations to support the organizational goals; execute strategic community engagement initiatives; introduce and implement best community engagement practices and processes; determine optimal avenues for promoting and marketing the DOC brand; attend meetings, community events, and forums; provide information and feedback on strategic partnership efforts to senior leadership; ensure community engagement strategies are strongly aligned with organizational goals; conduct research for various grant sources and potential funding sources to expand the DOC varied programs; persuasively communicate the departmentâ€™s mission, goals, reform agenda and programs to potential funders, external partners, businesses and community organizations; maintain and track marketing and community outreach activities; proofread and edit outreach communication materials and publications; ensure consistency of brand messaging in outreach materials; and perform related duties as assigned.

job_description: The NYC Department of Homeless Services (DHS) seeks one (1) Summer Graduate Intern for the Emergency Preparedness and Operations Unit (housed within the Division of Security and Emergency Operations).  The selected candidate will be responsible for both internal agency preparedness activities, such as working on the Agency's continuity of operations plan, hazard specific planning (e.g. how the agency would respond and take care of its clients in the event of a coastal storm or pandemic) as well as citywide planning regarding emergency shelter planning for the City of New York.  The unit manages DHS' involvement in New York City's Coastal Storm Plan - a plan developed by the Office of Emergency Management (OEM) to deal with the effects of a hurricane hitting New York City in which DHS is the lead agency on sheltering.  This project has encompassed all facets of operationalizing the emergency sheltering system conceived in the Plan such as strategic stockpiling of supplies, staff recruitment efforts, exercise drills, information management systems development, training development, and coordination with government agencies and voluntary organizations.    The intern will focus on DHS' emergency operations and will be assigned to a variety of significant and high profile projects associated with the Coastal Storm Plan such as hurricane exercise drills, staff and volunteer recruitment, and information system development as well as DHS agency preparedness projects.  There will be opportunities for the intern to manage special projects from inception to completion during the duration of the internship.

job_description: The Department of Finance seeks an experienced individual to serve as a Data Analyst/Modeler in the Tax Policy Division, Data Intelligence Group (DIG).  The selected candidate will assist with the development of computer programs and data models.  Models and analyses will be performed using SAS.  DIG is responsible for using tax and audit data to:     - Build a sound data infrastructure for use in audit selection;   - Develop modeling and data mining techniques; and   - Develop enhanced matching programs using a variety of data sources in order to identify     non-filers and underreporters for the purpose of bringing them into compliance with City tax     laws.  	 Reporting to the Director, the responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following:   - Provide technical computer programming and data analysis support to the agencyâ€™s     modeling and computer assisted audit functions.  - Assist with production of sophisticated predictive modeling to produce audit-worthy     candidates.  - Use SAS to merge and manipulate large datasets and critically analyze statistical findings.  - Work closely with staff from Tax Policy and other divisions to successfully implement and     track results.  - Conduct analysis on the expected impact of proposed changes to tax law.  - Construct policy option simulations using computer programs.  - Use taxpayer transactional data in various formats to construct statistical samples for audit     purposes.  - Respond to ad-hoc data and reporting requests.  - Assist with data-mining and model development in order to identify audit candidates.
minimum_qual_requirements: (1) A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college, including or supplemented by twenty-four (24) semester credits in computer science or a related computer field; or  (2) A four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent plus (3) years of satisfactory fulltime computer programming experience; or  (3) A satisfactory combination of education and experience that is equivalent to (1) or (2) above. College education may be substituted for up to one year of the experience required in (2) above on the basis that sixty (60) semester credits from an accredited college is equated to one year of experience. In addition, twenty-four (24) credits from an accredited college or graduate school in computer science or a related computer field, or a certificate of at least 625 hours in computer programming from an accredited technical school (post high school) may be substituted for one year of experience. However, all candidates who attempt to qualify under option (3) must have at least a four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and at least (1) year of satisfactory full-time computer programming experience.     Some examples of unacceptable experience are: End users of a computer system, program or software package; experience in the areas of end user computer technical support, computer operations, data entry/data retrieval, quality assurance (QA); end user hardware installation; end user help desk; teaching, telecommunications, experience in Microsoft Office Suite/Back Office products.
preferred_skills: â€¢ Strong qualitative and quantitative analysis skills. â€¢ Strong programming, data analysis, statistical sampling and data mining experience. â€¢ Proficiency in SAS programming strongly preferred. â€¢ Knowledge of XML a plus.

job_description: The New York City Department of Investigation (â€œDOIâ€) is one of the oldest law enforcement agencies in the country with a mission of combating municipal corruption. The selected candidate will manage the operations of an Inspector General Squad that provides oversight of multiple City agencies. The Division of Disease Control PCSI Initiative is seeking a City Research Scientist II to work on a range of projects, including a project to improve sexual health screening at select Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs).  The successful candidate will report to the Director, PCSI at DOHMH Gotham Center, located in Long Island City, Queens.  There will be limited local travel. job_description: As part of the Mayorâ€™s Office of Operations, HHS Accelerator and Connect are the Cityâ€™s go-to resource for harnessing digital tools and capabilities to improve the lives of low-income and vulnerable New Yorkers, with the policy, management and technical expertise to help produce better outcomes for residents.  The first generation of products we operate are:   â€¢ HHS Accelerator is a transformational initiative to reengineer, simplify and speed the    procurement process for City agencies and client and community based service organizations    by implementing a series of policy reforms, restructuring of rules and regulations, centralizing    portions of procurement oversights and building a web-based system to support these    reforms to dramatically shift the Cityâ€™s procurement of health and human services.   â€¢ Worker Connect, a data sharing technology that allows case workers to see real-time    information about clients drawn from multiple City sources. Users only access information    that they have been authorized to view based on their role and all applicable laws and    regulations.  â€¢ ACCESS NYC, a website that allows New Yorkers to screen for eligibility for over 30 City,    State, and Federal benefit programs. Depending on the benefit, residents can apply online,    print out pre-populated application forms, and determine agency locations where they can go    to directly apply for services.   Together, these initiatives break information silos through the use of modernized technology and coordinated agency practices to more efficiently and effectively provide health and human services to New Yorkers. Our dedicated team is growing through adding new skillsets to enhance and expand the current products and create new digital services. Joining this team is an opportunity to use your expertise in digital services to create meaningful impact and help improve the lives of millions of New Yorkers.   As part of this unit, the Technical team supports Accelerator, ACCESS NYC and Worker Connect applications and is distributed into two teams. IT Product Development consist of Developers and QA Testers whose purpose is to engage with the project teams to fix, test and develop new and existing products. IT Operations consist of systems administrators and ETL developers whose purpose is to ensure that all applications (including some components of DHS CARES) are optimized and maintain high application up time.  Reporting directly to the Director of IT Operations, the successful candidate will serve as a Junior Java Developer to the Connect CCI/DataShare team, who will:     â€¢ Manage the development lifecycle for the Document Management Solution, comprising a     federated model and partner agency implementations of FileNet repositories.  â€¢ Administer of the FileNet components including application and system monitoring across     all environments.   â€¢ Develop solutions using FileNet P8 APIs and J2EE standards, maintain current software.   â€¢ Work with product service providers to open PMRâ€™s and assist in troubleshooting and     resolving problems in FileNet P8 applications.   â€¢ Install/upgrade FileNet P8 Components, Patches and Bug fixes.  â€¢ Create and update technical design specifications, design and implementation of     application enhancements, building and deploying the code.  â€¢ Develop/update ANT scripts for  deployment.   â€¢ Assist in setting up build environments.  â€¢ Identify the tasks and provide the level of effort to complete the tasks.   â€¢ Contribute to new technology projects as assigned and provide operations & maintenance     support for existing Document Management Applications.  â€¢ Maintain FileNet API and custom code used by FileNet.  â€¢ Maintain FileNet API and custom code used by FileNet.

job_description: **Open to employees who are currently serving as Public Health Advisers.  You must clearly state your Civil Service Status on Your Resume or Cover Letter. The mission of Bureau of Sexually Transmitted Disease Control (BSTDC)is to promote sexual health  and reduce impact of sexually transmitted infections in NYC. business_title: Director of Policy and Family Self Sufficiency Programs
business_title_phonetic: Director of Policy and Family Self Sufficiency Programs
job_description: The Division of Tenant Resources (DTR) administers the fifth largest Section 8 Program in the nation, serving over 37,000 households.  The Section 8 Program is a Federal Rent Subsidy Program administered by the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD).  Under the supervision of the Executive Director of Policy and Special Programs in the Division of Tenant Resources in the Office of Financial Management and Tenant Resources, the selected candidate will be responsible for assisting in formulating policy and procedures to carry out the mission of DTR, while conforming to the mandates of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD).  The incumbent will be responsible for the development of policy and its implementation in the Division of Tenant resources and will manage the Family Self-Sufficiency (FSS) Program.    Policy:  Monitor legislation and HUD notices that impact the Section 8 program and be sure to respond with applications when requested, policy change recommendations and advocacy for HPD as necessary based on current information.  The candidate will monitor the response to inquiries and maintain a good working relationship with the HUD field office, submit application for vouchers completely and timely.  The Selected Candidate will work to understand and communicate any relevant rule or regulatory changes introduced by HUD, analyze impact of changes and implement necessary changes.  Periodically monitor (through the development of the Administrative Plan) operations and address any inconsistencies with policies and regulations.  Develop communication tools with all stakeholders and review existing and proposed external HPD written material to assure federal requirements are met and high standards of accuracy and customer service are developed and maintained.  The candidate will be the primary liaison with auditors and lead on any internal audits in coordination with Director of Special programs.  The candidate will supervise the work of two policy analysts.    FSS: The FSS Program is an innovative program that provides a financial incentive for families to achieve stability and independence through education, employment, financial management, and other training and assistance.  The selected candidate will oversee operations of the Family Self-Sufficiency and Section 8 Homeownership programs.  This will entail developing and implementing policies and procedures for FSS and its complement Homeownership program.  The candidate will convene the FSSâ€™s advisory Program Coordinating Committee, expand membership and monitor partner relationships in collaboration with the FSS Program Coordinator.  The candidate will supervise the work of the FSS Program coordinator who supervises two team leaders and seven Case managers.  He or she will also oversee public outreach programs, ensuring that accurate information is relayed to landlords, tenants, the general public, elected officials and other governmental entities and oversee special projects as they arise.  He or she will develop and provide training to staff as needed.  In addition, ensure that staff members are working within Federal Regulatory and Local Policy Guidelines.

However, all candidates who attempt to qualify under option â€œ3â€ must have at least a four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and at least two years of satisfactory full-time computer software experience as described in â€œ1â€ above.    To receive credit, all college credits in computer science or a related computer field and/or the certificate in computer programming must be listed in Section A.6 on page 2 of the Education and Experience Test Paper.    Some examples of unacceptable experience are: End users of a computer system, program or software package; experience in the areas of computer technical support, computer operations; data entry/data retrieval; pure quality assurance (QA) auditing and   analysis; hardware installation; help desk; teaching; telecommunications; experience in productivity software products (e.g. word processing, spreadsheet, presentation, and database software, etc.); superficial use of preprogrammed software without   complex programming, design and implementation.
